question:
(a) Describe the characteristics of each of the following rock types
(i) Granite
(ii) Limestone
(iii) Graphite

(b) Explain how each rock type is formed
answer:
(a) The characteristics of the following are; 
(i) Granite

(i) Granite contains large crystals

(ii) They do not occur in layers or strata

(iii) They do not contain fossils which are the remains of plants and animals embedded in rocks.

Limestone:

(i) Limestone is arranged in layers or stata

(ii) They contain fossils

(iii) The rock is non-crystaline in structure

(iii)Graphite:

(i) Graphite is not crystaline

(ii) It is arranged in layers or strata

(iii) It may contain fossils

(b)(i) Granite is formed from the cooling and solidification of molten magma ejected from below the earth crust.  It cools before reaching the surface of the earth hence granite is called a plutonic or intrusive igneous rock

(ii) Limestone is formed from the remains of living organisms such as corals or shellfish. These remains have been cemented together under the influence of water to form organic sedimentary rock

(iii) Graphite is formed from pre-existing sedimentary rock called clay which have changed or metamorphosed to a new rock as a result of the influence of heat and pressure. Graphite is an example of metamorphic rock.

question:
Write explanatory notes on each of the following

(a) Land and sea breezes

(b) Temperature inversion

(c) Convectional rainfall
answer:
(a) Land And Sca Freezes: Breeze exchange between the land and the sea is attributed to differential heating of land and sea. These local wind are common in areas very close to the sea. During the day, the land is heated much faster than the sea and it is cooler than the sea at night. As the land is heated during the day, it causes the air to rise, creating a low pressure situation. Air therefore blows from the sea to replace the heated and rising air on the land thereby resulting in lower temperature and relatively cool air on the land. This is sea breeze which blows from sea to land. At night, the land becomes cooler that-. the sea having lost much of its temperature at a much faster rate than the sea. Thus, there is a high pressure situation on the land and a relatively low pressure situation on the sea. Hence a land breeze blows from the land to the sea.

(b) Temperati.re inversion: This is the opposite of lapse rate and it means a rise in temperature with increasing altitude. It is not in all cases that temperature decreases with altitude. Temperature could be lower at the sea-level especially in valleys almost enclosed by mountains than at heights above such valley E.g temperature inversion is found in European Alps where cold and heavy al: collects in valleys which are almost totally enclosed by mountains

(c) Convectional rainfall: This is the main type of rainfall in the humid tropics. The heat generated by the sun is aL;le to make the surroundings including the sea and ocean to be hot. Because the air is hot, it is able to absorb very large amount of moisture. The warm and moist air is forced to rise rapidly by convection current. When the current rises very high and reaches the cold layers of the atmosphere which make it conducive for the moisture contained in tha currents to condense, rainfall immediately fo: ows the condensation of the moisture. This type of rain formed by this process is called convectional rainfall.

question: Discuss the important features of Koppen's climatic classification
answer:
The important features of Koppen; climatic classification is based on vegetation. It attempts to explain the variation of earth's climate by studying the connection between vegetation and climate. Koppean's classification of climates consists of five major climatic groups which are

A- This is moist and hot climate e.g tropical rainy climates with avenge mz.nthly temperature of above 18°C. This climate has no winter seasons. Annual rainfall is large and exceeds annual evaporation.

B - This is dry climate in which potential evaporation exceeds precipitation. Since there is no water surplus, no permanent streams originate in B climatic zones.

C - This refers to moist and warm climate e.g warm temperate climate, whose coldest month has an average temperatures of under 18°C but has above 3°C in at least one month. It has both summer  and winter seasons.

D - This is snowy and cold climate (cold - snow forest climate). The average temperature of its coldest month is under 3°C. The average temperature of the warmest month is above 10°C

E -This is polar icy climate (snow climate). The average temperature of its warmest month is below 10°C. This climate has no true summer. In order to differentiate between sub-divisions within these major groups, secondary letters are assigned to furnish more complete explanation e.g

F - moist all year
M -monsoon conditions
S - dry summer wet winter
V - dry winter, wet summer.

A third letter was added to include information about temperature e.g

a - long hot su. rimer
b - short, warm summer
c - short and moderate or cool summer
d - very cold am; dry winter
h - hot and dry most of the year
k - cold and dry most of the year.

This is how these letters are assigned to climatic belts e.g polar and sub-polar (sub arctic) regions begin with the letter E, to which are added either T (for tundra vegetation and conditions). The dry climates are assigned the letter W and S to differentiate between desert (BW) and steppe (BS) climate and vegetation conditions. BWK would refer to cool desert climate while DFe would refer to cold snowy forest climate with cool short summer.

question:
(a) Describe the characteristics of the tropical grassland vegetation

(b) Outline the economic values of this vegetation type to the inhabitants of the region
answer:
(a) The characteristics of the tropical grass land vegetation include:

(i) Dry season lasts for 6-7 months

(ii) Tall trees reaching 2m dominate the vegetation

(iii) Scattered trees mainly in the river valley called savanna parkland

(iv) Around the equator the trees are bigger and more common than grasses called savanna woodland

(v) Towards the desert with less rainfall there are few trees with short grasses called savanna scrub. Some of the trees here e.g acacia, baobab, etc are deciducus (i.e shod the it leaves during the dry season)

(b) The economic values of this vegetation type to the inhabitants of the region include:

(i) Livestock farming (e.g cattle rearing) is the most important occupation E.g Hausa - Fulani cattle rearers, Massai of Kenya etc. are known to be heavily involved in livestock farming.

(ii) Grain cultivation: Some elements 3f grains such as millets, sorghum and maize are widely cultivated. Groundnut and cotton can also be cultivated

(ii:) Game reserves. Most of these grasslands serve as game reserves e.g National Park of South Africa and Yankari Same Reserves are centres of attraction for tourism.

question:
(a) Name two main types of environmental pollution and describe three causes of any one of them

(b) State three effects of pollution on man
answer:
(a) Two main types of environmental pollution are:

(i) Air pollution
(ii) water pollution 

Three causes of water pollution include:

(I) The release of disease-producing (pathogenic) bacteria and viruses (biological pollution diseases

(ii) Undesirable ions and compounds in solution (chemical pollution) into water thereby changing its colour, taste and/or smell

(iii) Oil spillage - the bursting of oil pipes results in oil spillage into water thereby changing the colour, taste and smell of the water.

(b) Three effects of pollution on man are:

(i) Atmospheric pollution, which may be caused by fog reduces visibility. This poses a serious danger to motorists and pilots

(ii) Pollutants may have adverse psychological effects on man and animals e.g discomfort, chronic diseases, such as lung cancer and asthma, impairment of growth and death

(iii) Some pollutants are toxic and can kill plants e.g sulfur dioxide and hydrogen fluoride are toxic to plants from which man gets his food.

question:
(a) Explain two physical and two human factors which may favour a rapid growth of population

(b) Outline five problems that may arise from the rapid growth of population
answer:
(a) Two physical factors which may attract or favour a rapid growth of population are:

(i) Favourable climate: This leads to dense population, e.g temperate regions like U.K. U.S.A Japan tend to have increased population because of good climate

(ii) Fertile soils. Fertile soils attract population, e.g fertile alluvial soil in the deltas of South East Asia, River Nile in Egypt have attracted dense population.

Two human factors which may favour a rapid growth of population are:

(i) Commercial activities, Commercial activities like heavy trading centres, and presence of ports are closely associated with population concentration

(ii) Mining activities. Mining activities in areas where minerals are available tend to attract high concentration of people.

(b) Five problems that may arise from rapid growth of population include:

(i) Accommodation problem

(ii) Transportation problem

(iii) High pressure on existing social amenities

(iv) High level of crimes

(v) Traffic congestion

question:
(a) Identify three types of rural settlements and describe the main characteristics of each

(b) In what four ways are rural and urban settlements interdependent?
answer:
(a) Three types of rural settlements are:

(i) Isolated settlement - One or a few houses only are found in a remote area

(ii) Two or more houses without shops, schools, or services also in remote area

(iii) Village - Many houses where several hundreds or thousands of people are found usually with small shops and limited services

(b) Four ways in which rural and urban settlements are interdependent:

(i) Rural settlements are sources of food for urban settlements

(i) Urban settlements are usually the sources of manufactured goods for the rural areas

(iii) Urban settlements are the sources of jobs or educational opportunities for the rural settlements

(iv) Urban settlements may also serve as administrative headquarters of the rural settlements

question: In what ways can transportation contribute to the economic development of any one country?
answer:
The contribution of transportation to the economic development of Nigeria

(i) It makes available to a community goods produced elsewhere

(ii) Transportation makes for regional specialisation in production. If goods are not moved, each region will produce less

(iii) Development of large cities depends on cheap and efficient transport system

(iv) It reduces the cost of goods to the consumers

(v) It reduces waste from over-production and stabilizes prices

(vi) it strengthens national unity as people from different parts of Nigeria easily interact with one another

(vii) It helps in national defense as troops can easily be moved to places where they are needed.

question:
Write explanatory notes on any three of the following:

(a) Government's influence on the location of industries in Tropical Africa

(b) Nearness to market as a factor of industrial location in Tropical Africa

(c) The concentration of manufacturing industries n urban centres of developing countries

(d) The predominance of consumer oriented industries in developing countries
answer:
(a) Government influences on the location of industries in tropical Africa. Government can directly or indirectly influence the location of industries. Such government influence may be owing to political, social, economic or military reasons. Government influences the location indirectly by offering incentives such as tax reliefs or low land rent, provision of basic amenities for the establishment of industries in an area.

(b) Nearness to market as a factor of industries location in Tropical Africa. Market is one of the factors affecting the location of industries. Industry will not be located where there is no market. Industries are located in areas of high population density because of the high purchasing power of the urban dwellers. Cost of transportation of manufactured goods is also reduced, and those industries whose finished products are bulkier than the raw materials are usually located at or near the market, e.g soft drinks and beer industries whose products are not only bulky but also breakable are located on or near the market.

(c) Concentration of manufacturing industries in urban centres of developing countries is due to

(i) Proximity to power, e.g electricity is easily available in urban areas

(ii) Supply of labour - due to high population in urban area, cheap labour can easily be available for the industries to use

(iii) Reduction in cost of transportation. Since there are good road network coupled with numerous vehicles, cost of transportation of both raw material and finished goods is reduced

(iv) Favourable market. Urban areas serve as good market for the location of industries because of high purchasing power of the urban dwellers

(iv) Easy source of capital: Most urban areas provide the means, i.e banks where entrepreneurs can easily get loan to boost their production

question: What five factors determine the volume of trade between Nigeria and Ghana
answer:
Five factors that determine the volume of trade between Nigeria and Ghana include:

(i) If the goods produced by both countries are not similar. If they are not similar, the volume of trade will increase, but if they are similar the volume of trade is going to be reduced.

(ii) Differences in climatic conditions: If there are differences in climatic conditions necessary for the production of certain crops, both countries will specialise in the production of different crops which will eventually lead to exchange of goods but if the climatic conditions are the same, both will specialise in the production of the same crops

(iii) The degree of industrial development: If one of the countries develops more industrially than the other, one will definitely demand for more manufactured goods than the other, hence exchange of goods (international trade)

(iv) Prices of goods offered: It the prices of goods offered by one of the countries is higher than what other countries may offer, the volume of trade will be increased but if the prices are low, one will expect a low volume of trade

(v) Foreign exchange earnings: If the foreign exchange earnings from both countries are high, then the volume of trade will increase but if the earnings are low the volume of trade will also be low

question:
Write explanatory notes on any four of the following

(a) Cocoa growing in western Nigeria

(b) Oil palm production in the eastern states

(c) Rice cultivation ire the middle belt

(d) Intensive farming in the Kano close-settled zone
answer:
(a) Cocoa growing in Western Nigeria: Cocoa is cultivated in the Western Nigeria especially in Oyo, Ogun and Ondo States because cocoa grows best under certain conditions present in these areas which are undulating and well drained land, temperature of about 27°C, rainfall of 125-200cm, abundant sunshine for drying the beans, abundant labour to work in the cocoa farm and easy disposal of produce through sea ports. Crops sowed mature within five years. Harvested pods are crushed,beans fermented, dried and bagged for export.

(b) Oil palm production in the Eastern States: Oil palm is produced in the east like Owerri, Aba, Port Harcourt, etc. The crop grows best in temperature of not less than 21°C rainfall of 150-300cm, brilliant sunshine, deep loamy soil coupled with abundance of cheap labour. The crop is grown from the nuts, matures within 5-10 years and the matured fruits or bunch are harvested; processed and the products are palm oil and palm kernel which are used locally or exported.

(c) Rice cultivation in the Middle Belt: Rice is cultivated mainly as food crop for internal trade. Swamp rice is the type that is mainly grown in the middle belt of Nigeria such as Lafiagi, Badeggi and Pategi areas of the Niger valley. The seeds, are first raised in nursery and later transplanted to the Niger valley where the Niger has flooded its valley. They rice grows between 3-4 months after which it is harvested, processed and sold to local buyers.

(d) Intensive Farming in the Kano close - settled Zone; Intensive farming is practised in Kano as a result of high population. This high population results in land fragmentation hence farmers have to maximise the use of the small land through farming. During the farming seasons, they apply fertilizers and manure to promote the growth of crops and most of the crops grown are mainly cereals e.g millet, sorghum, maize

question:
(a) On an outline map of West Africa, show

(ii) one area having rainfall all the year round
(iii) the position of the high pressure belt in January

(b) Give three reasons for the length of the rainy season in (a)(i) above

(c) Explain three problems that rainfall may pose to agriculture in (a) (ii) above
answer:
(b) Three reasons for the length of rainy season in the area having less than four months or rain annually.

(i) Long distance from the ocean. The area is too far from the ocean

(ii) Nearness to the desert. The area is very close to the sahara desert, hence it experiences low rainfall.

(iii) Effects of trade winds. The N. E trade winds tend to have more influence on the area than the S.E trade winds.

(c) Three problems due tc continuous rainfall all the year round are:

(i) Soil erosion: Too much rain results in soil erosion

(ii) Leaching: Too much rain leads to loss of nutrients from the surface of the soil

(iii) Poor yield of crops due to either damage to the crop or lack of sufficient sunshine to produce fruits.

question:
(a) Of what importance is the Aswan High Dam to the Nile Basin?

(b) Identify four problems resulting from the construction of the dam.
answer:
(a) Economic importance of Aswan High Dam to the Nile Basin are:

(i) Generation of Hydro-electric power (electricity)

(ii) Aswan dam also serves irrigation purposes. This enables the people to farm throughout the year

(iii) Dam is also used as fishing ground

(iv) Aswan dam also provides source of water for domestic and industrial uses

(v) Aswan dam also serves as tourist centre where revenue can be generated.

(b) Four problems resulting from the construction of dams are:

(i) There may be low level of water in the river which may hamper navigation and other activities

(ii) The collapse of the dam may lead to flooding of the plain which may cause damage to life and properties

(iii) Huge amount of money which would have been utilized in some useful projects is lost through the construction of dam
